column4: you could simply export CC="gcc-3.4" , or maybe change the gcc link to point to gcc-3.4
but before you do that, you might want to read up on nice , so you can see why the fact it's using 90% isn't really relevant
read up on nice?
it's a way to tell an app "As long as nothing else wants to use the cpu, you can use as much of it as you like, but as soon as another app wants to do something you WILL yield up the cycles"
why can't programs just remain dormant if not being used?
it's a daemon, it does stuff in the background. That's the whole point of a multitasking os, more than one app can run at a time.
another way to look at it is if your processor is doing nothing, it's wasting time. Find something for it to do when nothing else needs it
what I don't like is my cpu temps being as high as they are on max load.
then true, you can go to system->prefs->session and turn off the tracker. It won't run at the next login
thanks.
a wine app that couldn't run because your direct rendering is broken
if you have xserver-xgl running that would cause it
me.
seriously?
yes, its in my laptop. Instructions follow (unless you used the one from the ati.amd site, then all bets are off)
if you have to go, then I won't hold ya here.
nah, Jack was leaving
alright I'm ready for instructions.
system->admin->restricted manager, install ati . Reboot.  Log in, run fglrxinfo in a terminal, make sure you're using ati driver 8.37.6 . Done
how can I be sure i'm using 8.37?
fgrlxinfo will tell you
... it seems I was already using dri.. lol!
